Dear Mr. Watkins, Jr.:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 01/30/2023.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at .
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Mark Hunter, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all of the following
information:
• (d) Dates and places of contacts, names
of persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed,
their last names shall not be included in
the report.
Two of the three special evaluations reviewed had special evaluation reports that
included the last names of foster children in the home who were a part of the
special investigation.
CPA Rule 400.12205
• (8) An agency shall employ or contract for a
sufficient number of competent staff to carry out
the provisions covered by these rules. The
workload for each staff member shall not be
more than any of the following:
• (b) Fifteen children assigned to a social
services worker for purposes of providing
direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services
or a combination thereof.
Four of the child welfare staff had caseloads in excess of the acceptable limit.
Three workers had a caseload of 16 each and one worker had a caseload of 14.
The agency currently has hired additional staff who will enable/establish
compliance when training is completed.
CPA Rule 400.12327
• (6) An agency shall do all of the following:
• (c) Provide a copy of the report to any
social services worker that has children
placed in the home.
One of the three special evaluations reviewed did not include documentation the
social service worker with children in the home was given a copy of the
3

completed special evaluation. REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
PREVIOUSLY CITED 11/02/2021 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 11/18/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12418
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
One of the eight foster children records reviewed included an initial service plan
that was completed outside the time frame established by this rule. In this
example the initial time period ended 11/11/2022 and the initial service plan for
this time period was completed 11/14/2022. A total of 22 service plans were
reviewed as a part of this evaluation. REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
PREVIOUSLY CITED 11/02/2021 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 11/18/2021.
CPA Rule 400.12405
• (4) If an emergency change in placement is
necessary, then all of the documentation
required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule shall
be in the child’s record within 14 calendar days
after the change in placement.
Two of the eight foster children records reviewed identified at least one change in
placement that did not have the change in placement documentation required.
The first example had a change in placement on 09/20/2022 and 06/28/2022 that
did not include documentation for those changes. The second example had a
change in placement on 06/24/2022 and the documentation for this change was
not completed until 08/04/2022. A total of eight current foster children records
were reviewed as a part of this evaluation. Three of six changes in placement
were noncompliant.

• Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting

Report, to all participants (in person and by phone),

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the renewal evaluation completed
11/02/2021. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of that review were
326(1)(f)(g), 327(6)(c), 418(2)(a)(b), 607(4), and ISEP 4.22. Areas identified as
repeat noncompliance as a part of this interim evaluation were 327(6)(c), and
418(2)(a).
5

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment reviewed the corrective action plan for the
violations identified in the renewal evaluation report. It also reviewed any areas of
repeat noncompliance and the reasons the previous corrective action plan was not
successful.
Interviews
Child welfare staff participated in both entrance and exit conferences. No
outstanding concerns were noted. The ability to maintain adequate staffing levels
continues to present challeges for both administrative and line staff.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert involving an unlicensed relative home that had safety
bars on the windows for exits. The window bars included a safety button to allow
exits in the case of an emergency. Demonstration of the safety buttons was
completed with the foster care worker during a home visit and acceptable
documentation was received confirming compliance.
Foster Parent and relative comments to the analyst were generally positive and
indicated caregivers were appropriately supported by the agency staff.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
